S/CuMgAl-41 as an efficient Hybrid catalyst for asymmetric addition reaction in isopropyl alcohol solvent Yitao Gu a 1 Xiaoqian Ren b 1 Zihan Wei a Xiaoming Fu a Tianyi Yang b Chaofei Peng b Linwei Lu b Yiming Ma b Yang Xu b Huimin Zhang b Wenlong Xu c Jinhua Liang a ⁎ a College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, 211816, China College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 China aCollege of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, 211816, China b College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, 211816, China College of Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 China bCollege of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, 211816, China c Institute of Agricultural Resources and Environment, Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Nanjing, 210014, China Institute of Agricultural Resources and Environment Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences Nanjing 210014 China cInstitute of Agricultural Resources and Environment, Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Nanjing, 210014, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, 211816, China. College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. In this study, a series catalysts of CuMgAl-LDHs were successfully prepared by co-precipitation method. Subsequently, the catalyst S/CuMgAl-41 was prepared by modifying CuMgAl-41 with thiourea. The physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, ICP, FT-IR, TG-DSC and XPS. The catalytic performance of the catalyst was investigated. It showed that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibited synergistic catalytic activity with better ee value due to both acidic and alkaline active sites and confined spaces with proper interlayer spacing. When isopropyl alcohol was chosen as solvent, the S/CuMgAl-41 has the best catalytic effect for asymmetric aldol addition reaction between p-nitrobenzaldehyde (p-NBD) and acetone. Additionally, the process conditions for optimizing the asymmetric addition reaction have been thoroughly studied. It was found that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibited good reusability and stability. Moreover, the asymmetric aldol addition of acetone and p-NBD catalyzed by S/CuMgAL-41 can occur due to the result of synergistic effects of various factors, including acid-base active center, hydrogen bond, confined effect and anchoring effects between hydrotalcite laminate of S/CuMgAL-41. This novel catalytic design provides a new idea for asymmetric synthesis of p-NBD and acetone. Graphical abstract In this study, a series catalysts of CuMgAl-LDHs were successfully prepared by co-precipitation method. Subsequently, the catalyst S/CuMgAl-41 was prepared by modifying CuMgAl-41 with thiourea. The physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, ICP, FT-IR, TG-DSC and XPS. The catalytic performance of the catalyst was investigated. It showed that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibited synergistic catalytic activity with better ee value due to both acidic and alkaline active sites and confined spaces with proper interlayer spacing. When isopropyl alcohol was chosen as solvent, the S/CuMgAl-41 has the best catalytic effect for asymmetric aldol addition reaction between p-nitrobenzaldehyde (p-NBD) and acetone. Additionally, the process conditions for optimizing the asymmetric addition reaction have been thoroughly studied. It was found that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibited good reusability and stability. Moreover, the asymmetric aldol addition of acetone and p-NBD catalyzed by S/CuMgAL-41 can occur due to the result of synergistic effects of various factors, including acid-base active center, hydrogen bond, confined effect and anchoring effects between hydrotalcite laminate of S/CuMgAL-41. This novel catalytic design provides a new idea for asymmetric synthesis of p-NBD and acetone. Image, graphical abstract Keywords LDO Chiral catalysis Thiourea modification Aldol condensation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The aldol condensation is widely regarded as one of the most crucial organic reactions for catalysis in the constructing of new CC bonds [1,2], which are widely used in constructing natural and non-natural products with high atom economy. Eder and Hajos [3] first found that aldehydes or ketones with α-hydrogen atoms were eventually converted into chirality β‑hydroxy-carbonyl compounds catalyzed by (S) -proline in the 1970s [4]. The chirality of β‑hydroxy-carbonyl compounds are important intermediates in the synthesis of chiral chemicals, chiral drugs, and related materials [5]. In the past decades, chiral privileged catalysts have been explosively developed and used in typical enantioselective reactions, such as chiral 3,2´-pyrrolidinyl spirooxindoles [6,7], heteropolyanion-based ionic liquids [8] and proline-based organocatalyst [9–11], have been designed to catalyze typical enantioselective the reaction, while most efforts have been focused on tuning the typical scaffolds of L -proline or chiral pyrrolidine. Unfortunately, these organic catalysts cannot be recycled, thereby leading to inefficient resources of catalysts [12,13]. Solid catalysts such as l-Pro-LDHs [14], proline on H2N-MIL-101(Al) [15], and l-Proline/PEG/SiO2 [16] and L -/ D -Au7Ag8 [17] have been prepared by loading proline onto various solid supports to overcome the problems of cumbersome separation, difficult reuse and high cost [18]. To sum up, the active centers of these catalysts consist of both acidic and basic functional groups, which coexist peacefully on the enzyme catalysts, which synergistically catalyze the synthesis of chiral β‑hydroxyl carbonyl compounds from p-NBD and acetone. We envisioned that we could exploit a kind of like-enzyme catalyst with both high catalytic performance and acidic-basic functional groups. While the big barrier in the design of such catalysts is how to make them synergistically catalyze rather than neutralize each other. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs, [M2+ 1-x M3+ x (OH)2] x + (ax/n n−) x −•mH2O) consist of positively charged metallic layers and interlayer anions and water, have received considerable attention as catalysts due to their unique large surface area, high exposure of active sites as well as tunable acid-base properties, which have potential applications in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, such as hydrogenation [19], aldol condensation [20], Photocatalysis [21,22], catalytic oxidation [23] and adsorbent [24]. Moreover, the LDHs layer spacing is about 0.48 nm, which has the unique characteristics of nanolimited space in laminates [25]. Notably, previous work in our team [26,27] prepared a series of sulfur-modified LDH catalysts for the aldol condensation of p-NBD with acetone, the results show that the conversion rate of p-NBD is 97.4% and the selectivity of target product is 92.2%. Unfortunately, the enantiomer excess (ee value) of the product was not considered in this study. Thiourea co-catalysts activate electrophiles through hydrogen bonding, to thereby catalyzing catalyze the reaction. Under mild and alkaline conditions, Ketones and aldehydes can be easily converted into corresponding enolates, which firstly act as nucleophiles in direct aldol reactions. thiourea catalysts activate electrophiles to catalyze complexation and coordination reaction of sulfur atoms and metal ions through hydrogen bonding. While thiourea and substrate act as electrophilic activators to form a novel asymmetric catalytic system [28]. The study manifested that polar solvent was beneficial to increasing ee value of enantiomers [29]. Itoh et al. reported that selecting a solvent system with suitable polarity enables the synthesis of either anti- or syn-aldol adducts with excellent diastereo- and enantioselectivity [3]. Inspired by this intriguing literature, herein, we were devoted to design and synthesize thiourea modified LDHs catalyst, thereby investigate its asymmetric synthesis effect in p-NBD and acetone synthesis under mild conditions. Regardless of previous many reports, no study has been presented similar to ours, which provides a new attempt for asymmetric catalytic synthesis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The following analytical-grade inorganic chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd and used without further purification: p-NBD (97%), Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (99%), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99.5%), NaOH (96%), Na2CO3 (99.8%), Glycerol (99%) isopropanol (99%), acetone (99%), Anhydrous ethanol (99.7%), methanol (99%). Deionized water without carbon dioxide was used in all the experimental processes. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts CuMgAl-LDHs: The CuMgAl-LDHs were synthesized by co-precipitation method referred to [24]. First, according to the ratio of M2+/M3+=2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, respectively weigh a certain mass of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3) 3·9H2O, 8% of the Cu2+ doping amount, mixed with deionized water to prepare a certain concentration of mixed metal salt solution (A). Additionally, a certain amount of sodium hydroxide and anhydrous sodium carbonate were weighed and dissolved in deionized water to configure solution B. The solution A and the solution B were slowly added dropwise, maintaining a pH at 9–10, a controlled temperature of 60 °C and a rotation speed of 500 rpm for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution was centrifuged and washed with deionized water to neutrality. Finally, the precipitate was washed twice with ethanol, dried in a constant temperature drying oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The dried product was ground to obtain CuMgAl-LDHs. The hydrotalcite with different metal ratios was named CuMgAl-21. CuMgAl-31, CuMgAl-41 and CuMgAl-51. S/CuMgAl-41: 1 g of the hydrotalcite precursor CuMgAl-41 was mixed with 5% thiourea and dispersed in 100 mL of deionized water. The mixture was stirred under the condition of 1500 rpm, room temperature, and under nitrogen protection for 24 h. After hydration, the water was evaporated by a rotary evaporator. Subsequently, the resulting material dried and ground to obtain intercalated hydrotalcite CH4N2S/CuMgAl-41, and then the CH4N2S/CuMgAl-41 was placed in a muffle furnace and calcined at 500 °C for 8 h to obtain S/CuMgAl-41LDO. Finally, 1.0 g of S/CuMgAl-41LDO was accurately weighed and dispersed in 100 mL of deionized water, stirred for 24 h under nitrogen protection, and dried by rotary evaporation to obtain S/CuMgAl-41. 2.3 Characterizations of catalysts The crystal phase of the synthesized samples was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. A Bruker D8 ADVANCE with Cu Kα (λ = 0.154 nm) radiation: 40 KV, 200 mA, in 2θ ranging from 5° to 80° Emmett-Teller (BET) and nitrogen physical adsorption-desorption parameters of the sample were determined by nitrogen adsorption data obtained with a Micro-meritics ASAP 2020 analyzer, and the pretreatment was degassed for 2 h at 200 °C. The chemical bonding properties of the samples were investigated by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR, Nexus 870). The surface structure and metal elemental content composition of the samples were acquired by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, HITCHI S-4800) and inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, ICPE-9000). The types of acidic sites of all the samples were determined by Py-IR spectra, which were recorded with a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IT spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were carried out on an Axis Ultra DLD Kratos AXIS SUPRA instrument equipped with Al K α radiation (h ν =1486.6 eV). A benzoic acid-anhydrous methanol solution (0.02 mol/L, 30 mL) was added to a catalyst (0.250 g). The mixture was stirred for 60 min at room temperature under ultrasonic vibration. After centrifugal separation, the supernatant solution was titrated by sodium hydroxide solution (0.05 mol/L) using 0.5 wt% bromothymol blue methanol solution as Hammett indicator. Repeat each titration experiment three times. The calculation formula for OH− content is shown in Formula (1). (Formula 1) OH − concentration = c 1 V 1 − c 2 V 2 0.250 Here, C1 , molar concentration of benzoic acid anhydrous methanol solution (mol/L); V1 , use the volume of benzoic acid anhydrous methanol solution (L). C2 , the molar concentration of the standard solution of sodium hydroxide solution (mol/L); V2 , use the volume of sodium hydroxide solution (L). 2.4 Catalysts evaluation Aldol asymmetric condensation of p-NBD and acetone (Reaction Eq. (1)) was carried out as probe experiments in a 50 mL a three-necked flask Equipped with a condensing unit to explore the catalytic performance of materials. In a typical run, 1 g p-NBD, 5 mL acetone, 10 mL isopropyl alcohol, and a certain mass of catalyst were added to four flask with an oil bath at a certain temperature, followed by refluxing for a certain time under stirring condition. After the reaction, samples were taken for analysis and the remnant catalysts were washed three times with ethanol. Subsequently, recovered catalysts were dried in vacuum oven at 80 °C for 8 h, and then stored for reusing investigation. (Reaction equation 1) The products were analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with UV detection (λ, 254 nm). The HPLC column applied in this work was a Daicel AS-H column (5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm) with a flow of 0.1 mL/min at 25 °C, using 90% n-hexane-isopropanol as the mobile phase. In this paper, the external standard method was used to calculate the conversion of the raw material, while the area normalization method was used to calculate the product selectivity. The conversion of p-NBD and the selectivity and ee value of target A were calculated as Formula 2 - Formula 4. (Formula 3) Conversion = C A 0 − C A f C A 0 × 100 % (Formula 4) Selectivity = C R + C S C A 0 − C A f × 100 % (Formula 5) ee value = S R − S S S R + S S × 100 % Where, CA0 and CAf are the initial and final molar amounts of p-NBD, respectively. SR, SS are the peak areas of the R-configuration and S-configuration products, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of catalytic materials The XRD patterns of CuMgAl-LDHs with different metal layer ratios and S/CuMgAl-41 were invesgated, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig.1, the diffraction peaks observed in CuMgAl-LDHs are located at 2θ=11, 23, 35, 39, 47, 60, and 62, corresponding to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) crystal planes, respectively, which belong to typical LDHs diffraction peaks (JCPDS No.00–014–0191), indicating the successful synthesis of CuMgAl-LDHs [30,31]. It is worth noting that with the gradual increase of the proportion of layered metals, the crystallinity of the material gradually decreases. This can be attributed to the replacement of the octahedral structure of magnesium oxide and aluminum oxide with copper oxide octahedrons due to the increase of Cu content in the laminates. Consequently, the thickness of the layers and the interlayer spacing increase, which is consistent with a value and c value change trend of the cell constants (as shown in Table 1 ). The Ginger Taylor effect of Cu, attributed to the asymmetric d orbital, leads to the distortion of the copper oxide octahedron structure, which makes the octahedral composite salt preferentially synthesized in the synthesis, and subsequently influences the crystallinity of the material [32]. Therefore, when the ratio of layered metal (M2+/Al3+) exceeds 4, there are more variegated peaks in XRD besides the characteristic peaks of hydrotalcite. Based on these results, it can be concluded that when the molar ratio of M2+/Al3+ is greater than 2, the Al3+ ions of the LDH laminates become isolated from each other due to electrostatic repulsion, resulting in a highly uniform distribution on the layers. When the ratio is too large (>4), it promotes the formation of Cu(OH)2 and Mg(OH)2, leading to reduced crystallinity and the formation of other hetero-crystalline phases. Furthermore, Fig. 1 shows that the modified S/CuMgAl-41 still retains the structural properties of typical hydrotalcite. The diffraction peak of S/CuMgAl-41 is basically unchanged compared to CuMgAl-41, exhibiting similar characteristic diffraction peaks. The possible reason may be attributed to the well-dispersed thiourea, SO4 2− and NO3 − on the surface of the CuMgAl-41. Correspondingly, the unit cell parameters of CuMgAl-LDHs with different metal laminate ratios and S/ CuMgAl-41 are listed in Table 1. As M2+/M3+ ratio increases from 2:1 to 4:1, the charge density of the laminate decreases, which weakens the electrostatic repulsion between the positive charge of the laminate and the anion, and leading to an increase in the d003 and c value. Since the morphology of CuMgAl-LDHs did not undergo significant change with the increasing metal content in layers [33,34], SEM characterization was performed using CuMgAl-41 and S/CuMgAl-41 as representatives. The structure and morphology of CuMgAl-41 and S/CuMgAl-41 were characterized by SEM (Fig. 2 ). As observed in Fig. 2, the CuMgAl-41 sample shows rose-like structures with a well-developed layer arrangement. However, after modification with thiourea, the morphology of S/CuMgAl-41 is irregular while still maintaining the basical layered structural characteristics of typical LDHs, which attributes to reduction of material crystallinity during the roasting and rehydration process, as well as the mechanical stirring in the modification process. The textural properties were obtained through ICP-OES and N2 adsorption-desorption characterizations, the results are summarized in Table 2 and Figure S3. It can be clearly seen from Figure S3 that the isotherm corresponds to the CuMgAl-n1 and S/CuMgAl-41 are of type IV isotherms (IUPAC) with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesoporous pores in all catalytic materials. As seen from Table 2, firstly, as the proportion of metal in the layers increases, the specific surface area of the material gradually increases from 75 to 95 m2∙g−1. However, when the ratio of M2+/M3+ exceeds 4, the specific surface area of the material slightly decreases with further increase in the metal proportion of the layers, the reason may be that metal hydroxide or other impurities will be generated, which can block the pores and reduce the specific surface area when the proportion of M2+/M3+ is too large. Additionally, compared to CuMgAl-41, the S/CuMgAl-41 sample exhibits a significant increase in specific surface area (from 95 m2/g to 182 m2/g) and pore volume, which may be related to the looser pore structure of the modified material. The chemical structure of the materials was explored by FT-IR spectroscopy. Fig. 3 displays the FT-IR spectra of CuMgAl-41 and the modified S/CuMgAl-41 sample. It can be seen that the bands around 3406 cm−1 and 1652 cm−1 are observed in all the samples, which are attributed to the stretching vibration of the OH bond of the intralayer and interlaminar water molecules. The vibration of the CO3 2− appears at 1431 cm−1and could be assigned to interlayer CO3 2−, which confirms that CO3 2− is the anion between layers [35]. Bands below 1000 cm−1 correspond to vibrational absorption between cations and oxygen atoms of the layer [20]. The above are the characteristic absorption peaks of hydrotalcite structure. Moreover, the wide absorption band at 1135 cm−1 belongs to the symmetric O-S-O stretching coordinated to metal ions [36]. This confirms the successful synthesis of CuMgAl-n1 and S/CuMgAl-41, as evidenced by the presence of characteristic bands in their respective spectra. In Fig. 4 a, the TG curves exhibit two weight-loss segments, corresponding to the exothermic peak in the DSC curve. The first stage of weight loss for CuMgAl-41 occur from 150 °C to 210 °C, coinciding with the first internal heat peak (210 °C) on the DSC curve, which is mainly caused by the removal of LDH interlayer water or physically adsorbed water, and the weight loss during this process is around 16.6%. Obviously, the layer structure remains intact at this stage. The second stage of decomposition weight loss takes place from 240 °C to 590 °C, which is mainly attributed to the thermal decomposition of hydroxyl laminate and interlayer CO3 2− in LDH, including the second absorption peak at 383 °C on the DSC diagram. The weight loss in this interval is about 21% [37]. Fig. 4b depicts the TG-DSC curve of S/CuMgAl-41, the first decomposition weight loss stage of the S/CuMgAl-41 material occurs between 50 °C to 200 °C, corresponding to the first endothermic peak (178 °C) on the DSC curve, the weight loss is about 14.2%. Compared to the CuMgAl-41, the weight loss of the S/CuMgAl-41 is reduced, indicating an impact on the material's ability to bind water. The temperature range between 200 °C to 500 °C represents the second decomposing weight loss stage of the S/CuMgAl-41, which corresponds to the second endothermic peak (330 °C) on the DSC. Compared to the CuMgAl-41, the CuMgAl-41material exhibits a noticeable shift in the heat absorption peak compared to S/CuMgAl-41, suggesting a decrease in the thermal stability of the modified hydrotalcite. Which is attributed to the decomposition of sulfate formed by thiourea decomposition. The introduction of thiourea leads to a decrease in thermal stability. The OH−content of CuMgAl-41 and S/CuMgAl-41 samples was determined by the Hammett titration method, the results are shown in Table 3 . As shown in Table 3 that the OH−content of CuMgAl-41 is higher than that of S/CuMgAl-41. This difference can be attributed to the decomposition of thiourea at a high temperature of 500 °C into SO4 2−, which combines with the metal oxide to form an l-acid. Consequently, the basic amount of S/CuMgAl-41 is reduced. The catalyst acidity can be determined through NH3-TPD characterization, the results are shown in Fig. 5 (a). There are three desorption peaks in the spectrum, indicating the CuMgAl-41 and S/CuMgAl-41 possessing a relatively broad acid site intensity. Desorption below 300 °C attributes to a weak acid region, while the range of 300∼500 °C indicates a moderately strong acid. Desorption above 500 °C represents strong acidity. The acid sources of CuMgAl-LDH materials mainly consist of hydroxyl radicals and Al3+ [38]. Furthermore, compared to CuMgAl-41, it is not difficult to find that desorption peak temperature of the S/CuMgAl-41 has shifted towards higher temperature, which indicates that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibits stronger acidity. In addition, the peak area of S/CuMgAl-41 is significantly larger than that CuMgAl-41, indicating an increased acid content after modification and indirectly confirming successful loading. Fig. 5(b) shows the pyridine adsorption IR spectra of CuMgAl-41 and S/CuMgAl-41. All of the samples exhibit two distinct bands at 1445 and 1490 cm−1, which correspond to the pyridine chemisorption of the Lewis acid site [39]. It is worth noting that no peaks associated with Brønsted acid were detected because it is difficult to form Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface with the lower content water [40]. Fig. 6 shows the results of XPS characterization applied to S/CuMgAl-41 before and after p-NBD adsorption in order to understand the adsorption mechanism. The XPS signature of C, N, Cu, and S peaks are displayed in Fig. 6(a–d). As shown in Fig. 6(a), the XPS C 1 s spectra for S/CuMgAl-41 are deconvoluted into four characteristic peaks. The peaks locat at 284.61 eV, 285.83 eV, 287.93 eV, and 290.11 eV are ascribed to C–C/C=C, C=N/ C–O/C–S, C–N/C=O, and C=O, respectively [41]. After adsorption of p-NBD, it is found that the binding energy of C increases, which shows that the C atom is bound to the electronegative element, causing the binding energy to shift towards the higher values. The XPS spectra of Cu 2p are shown in Fig. 6(b), the two peaks with higher binding energy, located at 941.22 eV and 961.85 eV, correspond to the Cu2+ 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2, respectively, which are attributed to the spin-orbit splitting of the bivalent Cu2+. Moreover, the two peaks at 935.04 eV and 954.96 eV can be attributed to the Cu+ 2p 3/2 and Cu+ 2p 1/2, respectively, with a separation of 19.92 eV, suggesting the presence of monovalent copper (Cu+). After p-NBD adsorption, the binding energy of Cu 2p increased, indicating the reduction of Cu2+to monovalent Cu+due to the gain of electrons [19]. Fig. 6(c) exhibits a detailed XPS N 1 s peak. The N 1 s spectra are deconvoluted into four peaks positioned at 398.85, 402.07, 404.42, and 407.78 eV, which correspond to pyrrolic-N, CN, oxidized-N, and oxidized-N, respectively, which is produced during the high-temperature roasting process of thiourea. While after adsorption p-NBD, the N 1 s spectra are mainly deconvoluted into three peaks positioned at 397.24, 400.73, and 405.54 eV, respectively. It is found that the binding energy of N 1 s decreases, indicating that N can act as an electron-donating group to the conjugate π-system of p-NBD. The deconvoluted XPS S 2p spectra are displayed in Fig. 6(d), three peaks correspond to S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2, located at 162.24 and 163.90 eV, respectively. The spacing between these two peaks is 1.66 eV, which is quite larger than the pristine S. Moreover, two lower intensity peaks associated with oxidized S are observed at 166.62 and 170.3 eV. While after adsorption p-NBD, the S 2P spectra are deconvoluted into two peaks positioned at 169.28 and 172.46, which are also associated with oxidized Sulfur. It is also found that the binding energy of S 2P increases after adsorption p-NBD, which shows that the S atom is bound to the electronegative element. 3.2 Catalyst performance The Aldol asymmetric reaction of p-NBD and acetone was selected as the probe experiment to investigate the effect of different catalysts under the condition of 1 g p-NBD, 5 mL acetone, 10 mL isopropyl alcohol, catalyst dosage 5%(wt%), 60 °C and 15 h, all these data are presented in Fig. 7 a. As shown in Fig. 7a, the product yield and ee value increases with an increase in the metal ratio of M2+/M3+. Specifically, the product yield increases from 55.1% to 72.1%, and the ee value increases from 38.3% to 42.7%. An increase of the metal ratio of the laminate leads to an increase in the specific surface area and pore size of CuMgAl-n1 materials, which exposes more active centers and thereby results in higher catalytic activity. However, when the M2+/M3+ratio exceeds 4, both the product yield and ee value decrease slightly. This phenomenon is attributed to the blockage of the material pores and the loss of active centers. Therefore, the CuMgAl-41 has the highest catalytic performance, with a yield of 72.1% and ee value of 42.7%. The results show that suitable layer spacing and pore size are beneficial for the formation of target products. Compared to the CuMgAl-41, the catalytic S/CuMgAl-41 exhibits better catalytic performance under the same reaction condition, with p-NBD conversion of 87.4%, selectivity of 83.9% and ee value of 65.7%, respectively. Therefore, taking all factors into consideration, S/CuMgAl-41 catalyst is selected as catalyst for the following screening tests of Aldol asymmetric reaction of p-NBD and acetone. The Aldol asymmetric reaction of p-NBD and acetone, especially the conversion of p-NBD, selectivity of the main products A and ee value can be greatly affected by the reaction temperature with catalyst S/CuMgAl-41. The effect of reaction temperature on the Aldol asymmetric reaction of p-NBD and acetone was investigated under the condition of 1 g p-NBD, 5 mL acetone, 10 mL isopropyl alcohol, catalyst dosage 5% (wt%) and 15 h, The results were presented in Fig. 7(b). As depicted in Fig. 7(b), when the temperatures rise from 30 °C to 60 °C, the conversion of p-NBD increases gradually from 69.04% to 87.35%. Similarly, the selectivity of the main products A and ee value also increase gradually from 58.88% and 45.16% to 81.32% and 83.21, respectively. However, when the temperature further increases to 70 °C, the conversion of p-NBD, selectivity of the main products A and ee value begin to decrease gradually. Therefore, it is clear from the above results that 60 °C can be chosen as the optimal reaction temperature. The influence of reaction time on the Aldol asymmetric reaction was evaluated and presented in Fig. 7(c), all reactions were carried out under the condition of 1 g p-NBD, 5 mL acetone, 10 mL isopropyl alcohol, catalyst dosage 5%(wt%) and 60 °C. As shown in Fig. 7(c), an increase of reaction duration time can enhance the conversion of p-NBD, the selectivity of target A as well as ee value. However, after prolonging the reaction time, the conversion of p-NBD, the selectivity of target A as well as ee value begin to decrease, which can be attributed to the occurrence of side reactions. So optimal reaction time is 12 h. The catalyst of S/CuMgAl-41 recycling was studied by the repeated use for 5 cycles in the Aldol asymmetric reaction of p-NBD and acetone under same reaction conditions (1 g p-NBD, 5 mL acetone, 10 mL isopropyl alcohol, catalyst dosage 5%(wt%), 12 h and 60 °C). The 5% catalyst amount used in reusability studies remains unchanged, which minimizes the influence of catalyst losses that may occur in the wash and ultrasonic of the catalyst. After each cycle, the catalyst was filtered, washed with acetone and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The results of catalysts reusable performance are shown in Fig. 7(d), as shown in Fig. 7(d), there is almost no obvious change in the conversion of p-NBD, the selectivity of target main products A as well as ee value, suggesting its potential industrial application value. Figure S2 shows the XRD patterns of the catalyst before and after recycling. From Figure S2(a), it can be observed that there is little change in the crystal structure and compound composition of the catalyst before and after recycling. Figs. S2(b) and (c) display the SEM images of the catalyst before and after repeated use. It can be seen that the layered structure of the catalyst partially recovers after cyclic use, which can be attributed to the memory effect of the LDH during the washing process, restoring its originally partial layered structure, however, due to the short washing contact time, it is impossible to completely restore the state of hydrotalcite before calcination. In general, the electron nature and position of substituents on the aromatic aldehydes significantly affect the conversion of p-NBD, selectivity of the main products A and ee value. The condensation of various substituted benzaldehydes with ketones were evaluated under optimized conditions, the results are summarized in Table 4 . As seen in Table 4, the benzaldehydes with strong electron-withdrawing groups (Table 4 entries 1, 2, 7, 9) exhibit a good effect on conversion, selectivity and ee value. On the contrary, the aromatic aldehydes with electron-donating substituents (Table 4, entries 4, 5, 6, 8) did not proceed to react smoothly. Moreover, due to the steric hindrance of the -NO2 group on aromatic aldehydes, the effect of the position of the -NO2 group on the conversion of NBD is p> m > o (Table 4 entry 1, 7 and 9). While for p- Chlorobenzaldehyde(p-CBD) (Table 4 entry 3). On the other hand, - Cl group should be electron-withdrawing groups, but - Cl group is easily formed p-π conjugation owing to -Cl having three pairs of P electrons, resulting in a uniform distribution of electron clouds, showing electron-donating on the whole. So reaction of p-CBD and ketone show no ee value, either. Which is perfectly consistent with the fact that electron-giving groups reduce the selectivity of the enantiomers, while electron-drawing groups increase the selectivity of the enantiomers [42] under the same catalytic conditions. The reason maybe that the electron-withdrawing substituents decrease the electron density of the carbon-carbon double bond, making the carbon-carbon double bond susceptible to being nucleophilically attacked. While the electron-donating substituents increase the electron density of the carbon-carbon double bond, making the nucleophilic attack of carbon-carbon double bond more difficult. It has been proven that polar solvents have important effects on the catalytic activity, selectivity and ee value of aldol adducts [43]. The Table 5 evaluated the effects of a series of polar solvents of alcohols on the asymmetric aldol addition of p-NBD and acetone. As seen from Table 5, the selectivity of alcohol products and the ee value of R-enantiomer products gradually increased with the increase of carbon chain. Among them, isopropyl alcohol was used as the solvent, resulting in an ee value of R-enantiomer products up to 78.9%. Conversely, as the number of hydroxyl groups increases, the selectivity of the selectivity of target A and the ee value of R-enantiomer products decrease gradually. As the chain increases (Table 5, entries1, 2, 3), the longer the carbon chain, the lower the ability of the solvent to form hydrogen bonds. In the case of polyols solvents (Table 5, entries1, 4, 5), with an increase of hydroxyl group in polyols, more -OHs interfere with hydrogen bond formation, so the catalytic effect of catalyst is weakened. Therefore, when isopropyl alcohol is used as the solvent, the shape selection of chiral Aldol reaction is the best under the S/CuMgAl-41 catalyst. 3.3 Possible reaction mechanism The proposed mechanism of the asymmetric aldol addition of p-NBD with acetone catalyzed S/CuMgAL-41 is depicted in Fig. 8 . Firstly, as seen from Table 2 and Fig. 7a, adjusting LDH metal ratio of M2+/M3+ can further control interlayer distance and catalytic performance. So, LDH catalyst with proper interlayer space is one of the necessary conditions for ensuring good ee. Secondly, catalyst with spacing 0.304 nm S/CuMgAl-41 has both acidic groups (SO4 2− and NO3 −) and alkaline group (OH−), showing that their enzyme-like confined spaces and both acidic groups (SO4 2− and NO3 −) and alkaline group (OH−) can facilitate asymmetric catalysis synergistically. In detail, in the confined spaces of the LDH nanosheets interlayer, NO3 2− and SO4 2− come from calcination of S/CuMgAL-41(CuMgAL-41modified by thiourea), which bond with the metal oxide on the surface of the LDH layer, the O− on the -NO2 of p-NBD is fixed by hydrogen bonding with the NO3 − bonded to the metal oxide. As the same time, the O− of SO4 2− is fixed by hydrogen bonding with H+ on the -CHO of p-NBD, which attack the carbonyl oxygen atom of p-NBD to lead to one of the electrons of the C=O covalent bond to transfer to the oxygen atom and enhance the electrophilicity of aldehydes. Meanstime, hydroxyl between interpolates of LDHs activates acetone to produce enols, synergistically. Subsequently, the C− ions on the enol attack the C+ ions of the active p-NBD only from one direction for nucleophilic addition to produce product A or further generate B after dehydration (reaction Eq. (1)). It is worth noting that anchoring effect of p-NBD with NO3 2− and SO4 2− by hydrogen and confined effects of enzyme-like S/CuMgAL-41, which attribute to stereoselectivity of main products. In this reaction system, NO3 2− and SO4 2− come from calcination of CuMgAL-41 modified by thiourea not only enhance the electrophilicity of aldehydes but also anchor of p-NBD with NO3 2− and SO4 2− by hydrogen, thereby increase the selectivity of the entantiomers and ee value [44]. Hence, the asymmetric aldol addition of p-NBD with acetone catalyzed S/CuMgAL-41 is the synergistic result of diverse factors such as the acid-base active center on the S/CuMgAL-41, hydrogen bonding, confined effect and anchoring effect. 4 Conclusion In summary, enzyme-like catalyst S/CuMgAL-41 with confined space was successfully constructed by coprecipitation and thiourea modification. The results from Hammett titration and NH3-TPD analysis indicate that the S/CuMgAl-41 is a bifunctional catalyst with both acidic and alkaline active sites. Their catalytic properties of asymmetric aldol addition for p-NBD and acetone were further studied under isopropyl alcohol solvent. Under the same reaction conditions, the ee value catalyted by S/CuMgAl-41 is much higher than that of any other catalyst. The catalytic performance tests of asymmetric synthesis for p-NDB with acetone over different catalysts in isopropanol solvent obviously show that the S/CuMgAl-41 has the best catalytic effect, the conversion of p-NDB, the selectivity of main product A and ee value are 76.9%, 81.5% and 83.1% under the optimal reaction conditions, respectively. Moreover, S/CuMgAl-41 exhibits excellent reusability and stability. The S/CuMgAl-41 after modified by thiourea can provide an acid-base bifunctional active site, confined effect, anchoring effect, and hydrogen bonding environment, which are conducive to nucleophilic addition reaction and stereoselectivity. Hence, the asymmetric aldol addition of p-NBD with acetone catalyzed S/CuMgAL-41 is the synergistic result of diverse factors such as the acid-base active center on the S/CuMgAL-41, hydrogen bonding, confined effect, anchoring effect. This catalytic design method provides new ideas for the asymmetric synthesis of p-NDB and acetone. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a series catalysts of CuMgAl-LDHs were successfully prepared by co-precipitation method. Subsequently, the catalyst S/CuMgAl-41 was prepared by modifying CuMgAl-41 with thiourea. The physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, ICP, FT-IR, TG-DSC and XPS. The catalytic performance of the catalyst was investigated. It showed that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibited synergistic catalytic activity with better ee value due to both acidic and alkaline active sites and confined spaces with proper interlayer spacing. When isopropyl alcohol was chosen as solvent, the S/CuMgAl-41 has the best catalytic effect for asymmetric aldol addition reaction between p-nitrobenzaldehyde (p-NBD) and acetone. Additionally, the process conditions for optimizing the asymmetric addition reaction have been thoroughly studied. It was found that S/CuMgAl-41 exhibited good reusability and stability. Moreover, the asymmetric aldol addition of acetone and p-NBD catalyzed by S/CuMgAL-41 can occur due to the result of synergistic effects of various factors, including acid-base active center, hydrogen bond, confined effect and anchoring effects between hydrotalcite laminate of S/CuMgAL-41. This novel catalytic design provides a new idea for asymmetric synthesis of p-NBD and acetone.
coredata.dc:title: S/CuMgAl-41 as an efficient Hybrid catalyst for asymmetric addition reaction in isopropyl alcohol solvent
